Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Solutions for Renewable and Sustainable Fuels in the 21st Century

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) project supports the development at Rutgers University of a multidisciplinary, multi-institutional graduate training program in the area of renewable and sustainable fuel solutions. Together with partner institutions Virginia Union University, Delaware State University and the University of Puerto Rico, this program emphasizes broad training that will produce a new generation of leaders and professionals who can design and implement sustainable solutions for renewable fuels worldwide. Graduate trainees will all be exposed to fundamentals in biotechnology, chemistry, ecology, engineering and energy policy through course work as well as internships and training opportunities in industry, government and academia. The program will emphasize global awareness in energy research and the broad political and economic implications of fuel solutions for 6.6 billion people today and future generations. Participating faculty from Rutgers will present research at large minority-serving institutions, historically black colleges and universities, and women's colleges in the United States in order to attract students from these institutions to the IGERT project. Coordinating through the Rutgers Energy Institute and Biotechnology Center for Agriculture and the Environment, participants from 14 research Institutes and Centers at Rutgers University will partner with institutions in Brazil, China and South Africa to further expose IGERT trainees to complexities of the fuel problem worldwide. As such, it is expected that many of the graduates from this IGERT program will become leaders and experts to shape our country's future energy economy and policy, thereby benefiting the Nation's energy security and approach to the related complex issue of climate change. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Sustainable Fuels IGERT project's objective is to produce potential leaders in the important renewable energy sector through a combination of knowledge-broadening courses and experiential learning modules. Over the 6 years of this project, our IGERT provided a knowledge base and experience for graduate students across the campus, so that they developed the cross discipline perspectives that will be required to build novel alternative energy systems in complex team environments.  Our project created comprehensive curricula that provided a focused, but broad-scale and inclusive education and research program in all aspects of sustainability of biofuels, and provided our trainees with the skills needed to address this complex problem that transcends country boundaries, scientific disciplines, and cultures across the world.  Renewable energy is in particular a highly collaborative science that will require team building, strategy, and global thinking.  Experiential activities involving first-handed exposure to international partners in Brazil, China and South Africa provided critical global perspectives in our trainees as well as participating faculties in our project.  In addition, generous support from Rutgers Administration enabled our project to fund extended research visits by some of our trainees to institutions that are located in France, Belgium and Canada.  In our internal assessment, most if not all of the trainees emerging from our program have been trained to converse about energy fluently across disciplines, and participation in team projects provided each of them unique cross-disciplinary training that added exceptional value to their graduate education experience. Chemists have attended meetings of policy makers, engineers went to biology seminars related to biofuels at symposia, and biologists learned about how engineers think through working with them in teams. Our IGERT project thus successfully carried out a program rooted in bringing stakeholders, faculties and students together to discuss and debate issues.  Another important outcome is that interdisciplinary project components were successfully fostered in the graduate research of all our trainees.
